document.docAuthor: Grevea, Caroline, Schwertnerb, Cristiano F. & Grazia, Jocelia
document.masterDocTitle: Cladistic analysis and synopsis of Chloropepla Stål (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Pentatomidae) with the description of three new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cladistic analysis and synopsis of Chloropepla Stål (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Pentatomidae) with the description of three new species

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Departamento de Zoologia, Av. Bento Gonçalves 9.500, 91501 - 970 Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil

Laboratório de Ecologia e Sistemática, Departamento de Ciências Biológicas, Programa de Pós-Graduação em Ecologia e Evolução, Universidade de São Paulo, Rua Prof. Artur Riedel 275, 09972 – 270 Diadema-SP, Brazil
Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Departamento de Zoologia, Av. Bento Gonçalves 9.500, 91501 - 970 Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil

subSubSection.paragraph: This species can be diagnosed by the shape of the dorsal expansions of the hypandrium, especially by the two apical processes. Also, the shape of the posterolateral angles of pygophore (flat and quadrangular) is unique. The female genitalia is also diagnostic with the presence of a carina on the surface of gonocoxites 8, and the strongly convex gonocoxites 9.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 15.
Chloropepla costaricensis
sp.n. , male external and internal genitalia: (A, B) Pygophore: (A) dorsal view; (B) ventral view. Abbreviations: dr, dorsal rim; hy, hypandrium; lpr, lateral process of hypandrium; mp, marginal process of dorsal rim; pa, paramere; pan, posterolateral angle of pygophore; ppr, posterior process of hypandrium; vr, ventral rim; vw, ventral wall of hypandrium; X, segment X. Scale bars = 1 mm.

Fig. 16.
Chloropepla costaricensis
sp.n. , female external and internal genitalia: (A) genital plates; (B) gonocoxites and gonapophyses of ninth segment and ectodermal genital ducts. Abbreviations: aac, anterior annular crest; cs, capsula seminalis; ch, chitinellipsen; g9, gonapophyses 9; gc8, gonocoxites 8; gc9, gonocoxites 9; la8, laterotergites 8; la9, laterotergites 9; pac, posterior annular crest; pco, pars communis; pi, pars intermedialis; tvi, thickening of vaginal intima; X, segment X. Scale bars = 1 mm.

Male genitalia ( Fig. 15A,B ). Pygophore quadrangular ( Fig. 15A,B ), nearly as long as wide. Median region of dorsal rim ( Fig. 15A , dr) sinuous; lateral third of dorsal rim folded toward genital chamber; marginal processes of dorsal rim triangular ( Fig. 15A , mp), closely related to the parameres ( Fig. 15A , pa). Posterolateral angles flat, quadrangular ( Fig. 15A , pan). Median excavation of ventral rim V-shaped in ventral view ( Fig. 15B , vr). Hypandrium surpassing ventral rim ( Fig. 15A,B , hy); with 1+1 broad laminar-like expansions flanking segment X, dorsally bearing two narrow, apical rounded processes: one laterad ( Fig. 15A , lpr) and other backward directed ( Fig. 15A , ppr); ventral wall shorter than dorsal expansions, in a channel-like structure ( Fig. 15B , vw). Parameres spatulated, apical and medial spines present. Segment Xogival ( Fig. 15A, X ), with 1 +1 tubercle laterad to the constriction line. Male not dissected.

Female genitalia ( Fig. 16A,B ). Gonocoxites 8 quadrangular ( Fig. 16A , gc8); posterior margin slightly convex; apical half of sutural margins divergent; transversal carina arising from the sutural angles. Laterotergites 8 and 9 equal in length ( Fig. 16A , la8, la9); posterior angle of laterotergites 8 acute; posterior angle of laterotergites 9 obtuse. Gonocoxites 9 trapezoidal, strongly convex ( Fig. 16A , gc9). Gonapophyses 9 with 1+1 triangular sclerotized areas ( Fig. 16B , g9). Anterior thickening of vaginal intima in a ring-like structure ( Fig. 16B , tvi). Base of internal rod of ductus receptaculi bulbousshaped. Capsula seminalis subcylindrical ( Fig. 16B , cs), with three processes variable in length ( Fig. 16B , pcs): two reaching the free margin of posterior annular flange ( Fig. 16B , paf) and another shorter.

Chloropepla costaricensis
forms a monophyletic group with
C. aurea
and
C. pirani
, by sharing humeral angles produced in spine ( 10 ) and femur apical process moderately produced ( 80 ).
The species was named after the country where the specimens were collected.
